pullRequest.body:
See #15371.

---

PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

#### Declarations diff

No declarations were harmed in the making of this PR! üêô
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:

```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.
üöÄ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by grunweg.
bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10227147058/job/28298279663)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10227147058/job/28298280037)

You have well-thought answers to all comments: let's have a second pair of eyes on this.
maintainer merge

Thanks for doing this! I have a few comments, which should be quick to address. 
maintainer delegate, i.e. feel free to maintainer merge on my behalf once you have addressed them.

You have well-thought answers to all comments: let's have a second pair of eyes on this.
maintainer merge

```suggestion
open scoped Classical in
```

I have used `open Classical in` instead of `open scoped Classical in` as it doesn't make a real difference (if it created a name conflict, one would spot it right away) and is a little bit shorter. If you want, I can change  all over the PR, just tell me.
Is this needed, or can you add suitable `DecidableEq` hypotheses?
I suspect the answer is "let's scope all the `Classical`s first to prevent more being introduced, and remove them later"

For each statement, I have tried to balance between ease of use and adding decidability assumptions. If we notice that some of my choices create friction elsewhere, we can go back and fix them later. For this one, my idea is that it is used to rewrite from left to right, so better let the user do this without `classical`.
Same question here.

Here it's an instance, so I definitely don't want decidability assumptions, to make sure it's available all the time. In general, in definitions and instances, `open Classical in` is always the way to go, while in theorems one has to double-think.

We also have instances which explicitly take a `DecidableXX` assumption...
(which does not mean you're wrong, but makes me think twice)
Same question here.
It's for rewriting from left to right, as above. In general, if decidability only appears on the right of an equality, I went for `open Classical in` for this reason.
Nice clean-up!
Does `open scoped Classical` also work? Would you like to use that instead? (Also applies in ~30 other places.)
Yes, it works, but doesn't make a difference and is a little bit longer.
Fair enough; I won't insist on that one.
Same comment as above.
Nice find!
Is there any reason to avoid the modern style ``` open CategoryTheory Limits` ?
No specific reason, I had just copied what was already there. Fixed!

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - chore: remove some uses of `open Classical`, part 2
